--0016e6d99d1bf1c84404bdea843a
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hi all,

I'm proud to announce my first GECCO paper!

Title: Accelerating Evolution via Egalitarian Social Learning
Authors: Wesley Tansey, Eliana Feasley, and Risto Miikkulainen

Abstract:
Social learning is an extension to evolutionary algorithms that enables
agents to learn from observations of others in the population.
Historically, social learning algorithms have employed a student-teacher
model where the behavior of one or more high-fitness agents is used to
train a subset of the remaining agents in the population. This paper
presents ESL, an egalitarian model of social learning in which agents are
not labeled as teachers or students, instead allowing any individual
receiving a sufficiently high reward to teach other agents to mimic its
recent behavior. We validate our approach through a series of experiments
in a robot foraging domain, including comparisons of egalitarian social
learning with baseline neuroevolution and a variant of student-teacher
social learning. In a complex foraging task, ESL converges to near-optimal
strategies faster than either benchmark approach, outperforming both by
more than an order of magnitude. The results indicate that egalitarian
social learning is a promising new paradigm for social learning in
intelligent agents.

Paper page: http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=127157

Github repository for all source code:
https://github.com/tansey/social-learning

A couple of things to note here that I believe will be very helpful to
anyone using SharpNEAT in general:

- If you're looking to do Lamarckian evolution, it turns out to be very
easy: https://gist.github.com/2410490

- We implemented backpropagation through time for the FastCyclicNetwork.
Using the SharpNeatV2 that is in the github repo, you can perform
supervised learning on a NEAT network very easily, enabling online learning
algorithms to be incorporated into SharpNEAT experiments:
https://gist.github.com/2410545

Colin, I'd love if you could take a look at the backprop implementation and
potentially integrate it into a future release of SharpNEAT. Outside of our
hacking of the FastCyclicNetwork class, it only required changing
permissions on a few properties here and there.

The caveats here are that the backprop implementation requires you reset
the network state at every activation to be correct. If you're doing
something where recurrent networks that maintain state between calls are
required, then the performance of this method is not guaranteed to work.

If anyone has any comments or questions on the paper, I'm happy to discuss
it!

Sincerely,
Wesley

--0016e6d99d1bf1c84404bdea843a
